Description: East Greek terracotta figure vase (plastic vase). Head and rim fragments of mould-made vase, possibly an alabastron in the form of a standing kore (Greek maiden). She wears a headband behind long hair parted centrally, falling in braids onto her shoulders. She has almond shaped eyes. Traces of red paint on hair. Orange-brown fine Milesian clay fabric grey core, abundant fine mica and rare white inclusions.
Curator's comments: This head fragment can be compared to similar pieces in the British Museum of standing Kore (GR1860,0404.57 from Kamiros), seated Kore (GR1886,0401.1398 also Naukratis) or as an alabastron (GR1861,0425.34 from Kamiros), all in similar micaceous orange fabric and all dated to the late 6th century BC (Higgins 1954, no.61). A close parallel is from Lindos, Rhodes, dated 525 BC - 400 BC (Blinkenberg 1931, pl. 85, no. 2115). It was originally thought to be made in Rhodes (Higgins 1954, 48-9). Probably from South Ionia, Jones' NAA analysis of GR1888,0601.659 also from Naukratis, places it within his East Greek, probably Milesian group (Jones 1985, 673). Blinkenberg, C. 1931. Lindos. Fouilles de l’Acropole 1902-1914, I. Les petits objets, Berlin. Jones, R. E. 1985. Greek and Cypriot Pottery: A Review of Scientific Studies. Athens.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (61)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.045) (Phase 1)
